activities.loc: Branch 3 - Hearing by Zoom.  See enclosed information.

result.execSummary:
On one or more charges in this case, Young J Choi was found not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect. The defendant was found guilty of actually committing the crime(s) charged, but was also found not to be legally responsible under Wis. Stats. 971.165 for committing the crime(s) because of the defendant's mental condition. The legal effect of a finding of not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect is that the court must commit the defendant to the custody of the Department of Health and Family Services.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

[MK] case called at 11:55am. 
Attorney Michael C. Witt in court.  DA Susan Happ appears for the State of Wisconsin.
The Court is calling this case after Attorney Witt alerted DA Happ and that Court that he spoke with Mr. Choi by telephone this morning to discuss the rescheduling,and Mr. Choi requested that the Petition for Conditional Release be withdrawn at this time without prejudice. Attorney Witt clarifies that the request for withdrawl without prejudice is so that Mr. Choi would have the ability to re-file a petition within the coming year.  Attorney Witt indicates that Mr. Choi told him he was putting his written request for the withdrawal of the Petition in the mail today. 
DA Happ preserves
Based on the representation of Attorney Witt, the Court grants the Defendant's request to withdraw his Petition.  The Court requires that the request be set forth in writing and filed with the Court within seven days. If for some reason it is detemined that Mr. Choi does not wish to withdraw his Petition , the Court finds good cause based on this representation to extend the hearing on the Petition from the 30-day requirement by statute.

Defendant Young J Choi in court, in-custody, with Attorney Michael C. Witt. DA Susan Victoria Happ appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
DA Happ summarizes status of case indicating that Mr. Choi will be entering a No Contest and Not Guilty by Reason of Mental Disease or Defect plea today, no written agreement on sentence other than understanding that there is mandated life sentence. Neither party is contesting findings of Dr. Frieburger.

Constitutional rights given; plea of "No Contest" & "Not Guilty by Reason of Mental Disease or Defect" entered; factual basis stipulated; Counsel stipulate to findings and opinions of Dr. Frieburger's NGI report; victim rights compliance verified; Court finds the plea has been entered freely, voluntarily, intelligently and accepts the pleas, finds Defendant guilty but Not Guilty by reason of mental disease or defect.
Counsel confirm they have been discussing sentencing dates with the Court's JA, but have not yet come up with time on 10/21/15
DA Happ informs the Court that she is unsure how long will need for sentencing, minimal, 1 hour
Atty Witt informs the Court that the defense will be standing on doctor's report
Court revokes bond, upon motion of State

Order for Involuntary Medication Pursuant to 971.14(5)(d), WIS. STAT

Case called at 1:00 pm [sf]
Defendant Young J Choi in court, in custody with Attorney Michael C. Witt. DA Susan Victoria Happ appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

Court reviews that hearing is on the reexamination of the defendant.
Attorney Witt advises that he has reviewed the Dr.'s Report and has reviewed it with Mr. Choi.
DA Happ confirms she has received the Dr.'s Report.
Counsel agree that this is a hearing under Statute 971.14(5)(c).  
Mr. Choi believes he is competent.
Attorney Witt believes that Mr. Choi has regained competency.
DA Happ agrees that Mr. Choi is competent
The Court finds Mr. Choi to be competent.

The Court references the findings made in the examining doctor's report and does opine that Mr. Choi does need to maintain medications in order to maintain competency.
The Court review that there is no State form and that DA Happ has drafted a proposed order to accomplish this.
DA Happ reviews that as a part of that order that the State requests that the Court find that the defendant should be returned to inpatient treatment under 971.14 (5)(d).

Court advises that it has contact the WCS/DHS Court Liasion Ms. Shequen, discussion was that once the defendant is found competent he should be returned to the jail.
Court and counsel discuss limitations under the statute as to Court's placement of the defendant once found competent.
Attorney Witt believes that statute allows the Court to make the requested specific orders.
Court reviews that a cash bail was ordered in this case, which has not been posted.

Court inquires of Captain Wallace if psychiatrist is avaiable to come to the jail to help maintain the defendant's competency. Captain Wallace informs the Court that there is not a psychiatrist available in the jail.
Court and Captain Wallace discuss the formulary available at the jail. Captain Wallace advises that the jail would do everything possible to follow the medication regimen provided by DHS.
Court finds that under the circumstances it would be folly to order the defendant be returned to DHS when DHS would turn the defendant away since he has been found competent.
Court will sign an order for the involuntary administration of medication and treatment but it will be administered at the jail.

Court examines the Defendant as to rights, understanding & intent.  
Mr. Choi waives his right to Preliminary Hearing; the Court accepts this waiver and binds him over for trial.
Court and Attorney Witt discuss filing of substitution.
Attorney Witt advises that he will be filing a substitution.
DA Happ informs the Court that there is victim rights compliance.
Court finds that there is victim rights compliance.
Court advises that it will not schedule any further hearings at this time based on Attorney Witt's indication that he will be filing a substitution.

recess: 1:31 pm

case called at 8:48am. [MK]
Defendant Young J Choi appears via videoconferencing from Mendota Mental Health Institute.  His counsel, Attorney Michael Witt, is present in court.  DA Susan Happ appears in court for the State of Wisconsin.  
The Court makes inquiries to the staffperson at MMHI to verify that Mr. Choi can see and hear the court proceedings. 
Counsel acknowledge receipt of Dr. Phelps' 12/30/14 Competency Report.
The Court summarizes that the Statutes do not cover the situation presented by this Report which indicates that Mr. Choi is still not competent, but that he is likely to become competent within the statutory period with medication and treatment, however there is no order for involuntary medication or treatment. Because the Report indicates that with medication and treatment Mr. Choi is likely to become competent, then under sub (C) and sub (b) the Court is not precluded from holding a hearing under sub (4). 
The Court cites the limited statutory time involved for Mr. Choi to regain competency; under these circumstances, the Court can hold a hearing under sub (4) even absent a motion. 
In response to the Court's inquiry, counsel agree that the requirements of sub (5)(b) are met within the Report. 
The Court believes it can appropriately operate under Statute 971.14(4); and that due process notice is provided to the Defense;  the Court is proceeding under sub (4)(b). 
recess 9:01am, reconvene 9:05am
On agreement of counsel, the Court finds that the videoconferencing system is sight and sound sufficient. 
The Court receives the stipulations of counsel regarding the doctor's qualifications, and regarding the finding of Dr. Phelps that Mr. Choi continues to be incompetent.   
The Court makes a good cause finding to receive the doctor's testimony by telephone under Statute 807.13(2)(C)
Dr. Mark Phelps- sworn & testifies (by telephone) 
--direct examination by DA Happ
--cross examination by Attorney Witt
--redirect examination by DA Happ
--recross examination by Attorney Witt
--examination by the Court 
--follow up examination by DA Happ
--follow up examination by Attorney Witt

Arguments given by Attorney Witt.  
The Court finds that the State has proven, by clear and convincing evidence, that an order for involuntary treatment and medication is appropriate. The Court concludes that it is unlikely that Mr. Choi will take the current medication or any other psychotropic medication at a level sufficient to address his illness.
Under Statute 971.14(4)(b), the Court finds that the State has met its burden for the Court to issue the order for involuntary treatment and medication.
recess 9:53am.

NEXT:  DA Happ is to submit a proposed order on a five-day objection basis
The hearing scheduled for 1-15-15 shall remain as scheduled

records.descr: DE not competent to stand trial, case suspended

records.addlTxt: Order of Commitment for treatment w/fax confirmations attached

case called at 2:22pm. 
Defendant Young J Choi in court, in custody, with Attorney Michael C. Witt.  DA Susan Happ appears for the State of Wisconsin.
The Court admonishes Mr. Choi regarding past conduct in hearings, and that the Court expects appropriate court behavior and possible impacts of future inappropriate behavior.
In response to the Court's inquiry, Mr. Choi indicates that he intends to represent himself at today's hearing. 
The Court will have Attorney Witt remain at counsel table with Mr. Choi to assist as standby counsel.

Mr. Choi asserts that he is competent to proceed.
DA Happ indicates that the State is in agreement with the conclusion of Dr. Berney that Mr. Choi is currently incompetent to proceed.

Dr. Kent Berney- sworn & testifies by telephone
--before testimony begins, Dr. Berney interjects that he was not anticipating being called to testify today and he does not have his report with him
--the Defense objects to the testimony proceeding wihout
--direct examination by DA Happ
--cross examination by Mr. Choi
--cross examination by Attorney Witt
--examination by the Court
--redirect examination by DA Happ
--recross examination by Attorney Witt

Young Choi- sworn & testifies
--testimony given by Mr. Choi
--examination by the Court
The Court indicates that the evidence is closed; the Court will not have State cross examine Mr. Choi.  
The Court and parties discuss that the Court cannot address the issue of involuntary administration of treatment and medications without the testimony of Dr. Smith; because Dr. Smith's evaluation is now over two months, the conclusions on this are not current.
  
The Court finds that Mr. Choi lacks substantial mental capacity to assist in his own defense.  The Court finds that Mr. Choi is not competent to stand trial, but that, with treatment and medication he is likely to regain competence.  
The Court will not, at this point, require the administration of involuntary treatment and medications.  
The Court suspends the proceedings and commits Mr. Choi for an indeterminate term not to exceed 12 months
The Court grants 105 days for time already served. 
Recess 4:14pm.

case called at 9:07am. 
Defendant Young J Choi appears via videoconferencing from the Jefferson County Jail, in custody.  Standby Defense counsel, Attorney Michael Witt, appears in court.  DA Susan Happ appears for the State of Wisconsin.  

Based on Mr. Choi's responses to the Court's inquiries regarding Mr. Choi being able to see and hear the proceedings, the Court finds that the videoconferencing system is sight and sound sufficient. 

Mr. Choi voices that he has not had a competency examination-- the meeting with the doctor in the Jail was not an examination. 
Mr. Choi indicates that he is of the opinion that he is competent to proceed to trial. 
DA Happ indicates that the State is in agreement with the examiner's conclusion that Mr. Choi is currently not competent, however with treatment he may become competent.
Attorney Witt indicates that, as Standby Defense Counsel, he feels bound to assert that Mr. Choi is competent. 
Mr. Choi indicates he wants the Court to rely on what he is telling the Court, not to give consideration to Attorney Witt. 
Mr. Choi requests "a correct evaluation" in a facility outside of the Jail. 
The Court orders a second competency evaluation, to be conducted at the Jail, not inpatient. The report is to be completed within thirty days.
At 9:15am, the Court directs the Sheriff's Deputies to remove Mr. Choi from the Videoconferencing Room due to his verbal outbursts.
The Court continues the appointment of Attorney Witt as standby counsel, indicating that, until Mr. Choi would be found to be competent, the Court cannot have a colloquy with Mr. Choi regarding waiver of counsel. 
recess 9:18am.

NEXT:  schedule Competency Hearing in approximately 45 days, allow two hours (Mr. Choi to appear in court for the hearing, not via v/c)

Case called at 1:22 pm (Judge Weston presiding for Branch 3)
Defendant Young J Choi in custody, via video from the Jefferson County Jail with Attorney Jeffrey De La Rosa from the Jefferson County Public Defenders Office. DA Susan Happ appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

Attorney De La Rosa informs the Court that the defendant would like to proceed Pro-Se.
Right to counsel given; constructive waiver of counsel warnings given
Defendant informs the Court that he would still like to proceed Pro-Se.
Upon stipulation, the Court finds the video connection to be sight and sound sufficient. 
Service of Complaint admitted; reading waived; charges and maximum penalties recited
Bail/Bond recommendations presented by counsel.

Court requires $1,000,000.00 CASH, with conditions: 
-Not to leave the State of Wisconsin
-No acts or threats of violence 
-Take all prescribed medications as prescribed or take substitute medications available to defendant at the Jail
-No contact direct or indirect with Marcia Grimmenga, David Gerard or Eric Pann
-No presence at 300 N. 4th St. in the City of Watertown 
-No possession of any dangerous weapons to include swords, knives, firearms or ammunition

Court will schedule Preliminary Hearing within 10 day time limit. 

Recess: 1:35 pm
NEXT: (Notices to be mailed)
Preliminary Hearing: 6/30/14 at 10:00 am
